questions.question: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive, and tachycardic. The findings of microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear are given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation: The description provided suggests a severe form of malaria, which is most commonly associated with Plasmodium falciparum.

questions.question: During your rural posting, a patient presents with a high fever and chills. Malaria is endemicin the area so you order a peripheral smear. While examining the peripheral blood smear, younote that the schizont stage is not seen. Which of the following organisms is implicated here?
questions.explanation: The schizont stage is usually not seen in the peripheral smear of individuals having Plasmodiumfalciparum malaria.A mature schizont contains merozoites and hemozoin. This will burst to release merozoites intocirculation. The merozoites invade fresh erythrocytes, in which they go through the same processof development called erythrocytic schizogony or merogony.After the ring form is formed in peripheral blood, the remaining RBC cycle of falciparum occurs inthe capillaries of the brain and other internal organs. Hence only the ring form is seen in theperipheral smear.542However, for other Plasmodium species, all erythrocytic stages occur in peripheral blood vessels.The below image shows the life cycle of Plasmodium spp.Infective StageA Diagnostic StageCDCSAFER HEALTHIER PEOPLEHuman Liver StagesLiver cellInfectedliver cellatDocst10 OokineteMosquito StagesRupturedcocystMicrogamete enteringmacrogameteCRelease ofsporozoitesMosquito takesa blood meal(injects sporozoites)Sporogonic CycleMosquito takesa blood meal(ingests gametocytes)MacrogametocyteExflagellated?microgametocyte"AExo-erythrocytic CycleRuptured schizontHuman Blood StagesSchizontImmaturetrophozoite(ring stage)BErythrocytic CycleMature,trophozoiteP. falciparumRupturedschizontSchizontGametocytes,GametocytesP. vivaxPovaleP malariae

questions.question: Which of the following Plasmodium spp. has the longest incubation period?
questions.explanation: Plasmodium malariae has the longest incubation period of 28 days.The incubation period is the interval between the infective mosquito bite and the first appearanceof clinical symptoms. The average incubation periods for Plasmodium species are:• P. vivax: 8-31 days (14 days)• P. falciparum: 8-14 days (12 days)• P. ovale: 8-31days (14 days)• P. malariae: 18-40 days (28 days)Note: The pre-patent period is the interval between the entry of the parasites into the host and thetime when they first become detectable in blood.

questions.question: Which of the following Plasmodium spp. mainly affects the old RBCs?
questions.explanation: Plasmodium malaria mainly affects the old RBCs.Options A and D- P. vivax and P. ovale infect young RBCs and reticulocytes.Option B- P. falciparum infects RBCs of all ages.The degree of parasitization is not heavy for P. vivax and P. malariae while very high intensity ofparasitization is seen in infection with P. falciparum.543

questions.question: A microbiologist is examining the slide shown in the following image under the microscope.Which of the following is false regarding this?A

options.A: 'B' is used for determining the species
options.C: 'A' is air dried rapidly and stained with one of the Romanowsky stains
options.D: For 'B' to be considered negative, at least 200 oil immersion fields should be examined

questions.explanation: In the given image 'A' is a thin smear and 'B' is a thick smear. The thin smear is used fordetermining the species, not the thick smear.The two types of smears are prepared from the peripheral blood are:• Thin smear- It is used for detecting the parasites and determining the species. They are air-driedrapidly and stained with Romanowsky stains.• Thick smear- It is more sensitive and examined under oil immersion microscope. It is moresuitable for the rapid detection of malarial parasites. Species identification is difficult. It isrecommended that 200 oil immersion fields should be examined before a thick film is declarednegative.The image below shows the thin and thick smears.Thin smearPeripheral smearOMARROWThick smear

questions.question: A 15-year-old boy presents to the OPD with high-grade fever, chills, and rigors for the past 3days. A peripheral blood smear revealed the following. Which of the following is falseregarding the diagnostic methods used to detect the condition he is likely suffering from?

options.A: Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya stain is used for peripheral smear examination
options.B: HRP-2 antigen test is done for detection of P. vivax
options.C: Acridine orange dye is used in quantitative buffy coat method
options.D: Rapid diagnostic tests have lesser sensitivity than microscopy

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the peripheral smear showing ring forms are suggestive of P.falciparum malaria. HRP-2 antigen detection used in rapid diagnostic tests for malaria is specificfor P. falciparum.Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya (JSB) stain is routinely used in India to stain peripheral bloodsmears for the diagnosis of malaria.Acridine orange dye is used in the quantitative buffy coat (QBC) method of diagnosis whichprovides better yield compared to peripheral smears.Rapid diagnostic tests are based on the detection of antigens using immunochromatographicmethods. They are less sensitive than microscopy and also cannot differentiate between speciesexcept P. falciparum. The 2 antigens detected are:• PLDH (parasite lactate dehydrogenase)- pan malarial antigen544• HRP-2 (histidine-rich protein 2)- specific for P. falciparum.

questions.question: A 50-year-old man with a 5-day history of fever is brought to the casualty by his son after anepisode of seizures. He is diagnosed with malignant tertian malaria. Which of the followingcomplications will you not expect to see in this patient?
questions.explanation: Metabolic acidosis (and not alkalosis) is a complication of malignant tertain malaria caused byPlasmodium falciparum.Complications of falciparum malaria include:• Metabolic acidosis• Cerebral malaria••Algid malariaSepticemic malaria• Blackwater fever• Pulmonary edema•• Acute renal failure• Hypoglycemia• Hyperpyrexia• Severe anemia• Shock

questions.question: A 24-year-old patient presents with a high-grade fever, headache, and weakness for 5 days.He gives a history of blood transfusion 4 months back. The microscopic examination of thethin blood smear is given below. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.explanation: The given clinical history and the microscopy showing Maltese crosses or tetrads are suggestive ofbabesiosis caused by Babesia microti.The definitive host for babesia are ixodid ticks. Man is an incidental, dead-end host.On microscopic examination, babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriformor ring form. The ring form is the most common and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit whichdifferentiates it from P. falciparum.Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence oftetrads/Maltese crosses, which are pathognomic of B. microti or B. duncani.The below image shows Maltese cross appearance of Babesia microti.545OMARROW

questions.question: Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for diagnosis of which of the following condition?
questions.explanation: Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis.It is based on the principle that the presence of anti-toxoplasma antibodies in the patient'sserum inhibits the staining of trophozoites by alkaline methylene blue dye.Toxoplasma trophozoites and complement are added to the patient's serum which is thenincubated for an hour at 37°C. After incubation, methylene blue dye is added.If anti-toxoplasma antibodies are present in the serum, these are activated by complement andthe parasite membrane is lysed. Thus, the trophozoites are not stained (positive result).If there are no antibodies, trophozoites will take up the stain and appear blue under themicroscope. This is considered to be a negative result.The dilution of the test serum at which 50% of the tachyzoites are not stained is reported as theantibody titer of the test serum. The test is highly sensitive and specific.It cannot differentiate between recent or past infections as it detects only IgG antibodies.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding Toxoplasma gondii?

options.B: Oocysts are formed within the intermediate host
options.C: The tachyzoites inside the tissue cyst can be reactivated on immunosuppression

questions.explanation: Human toxoplasmosis is a zoonosis. It is transmitted by cats.Toxoplasma gondii has two types of life cycles:• Enteric cycle• Exoenteric cycleThe enteric cycle occurs in definitive hosts such as cats. Exoenteric cycle occurs in intermediatehosts such as humans, mice, rats, etc.546Both asexual reproduction (schizogony) and sexual reproduction (gametogony) occur within themucosal epithelial cells of the small intestine of the cat. The tachyzoites and tissue cyst representstages in asexual multiplication, while the oocyst is formed by sexual reproduction.All three forms, tachyzoites, tissue cyst, and oocyst occur in the definitive host. Only the asexualforms, tachyzoites, and tissue cysts are present in the intermediate host.Tachyzoites continue to multiply and spread locally by the lymphatic system and blood, while thebradyzoites multiply slowly inside the tissue cyst. The dormant bradyzoites inside the cyst may bereactivated on immune suppression causing renewed infection in the host.The below image shows the life cycle of Toxoplasma gondii.Life cycle of Toxoplasma gondiiNIATransmissionthrough theplacentaIntermediate hosts:mammals, birdsBrain, heart,lung, eye,muscles,placenta.Blood flowdisseminationIntestinalcells

questions.question: An HIV positive pregnant woman was brought to the ER after an episode of generalizedtonic-clonic seizures. CECT was done which showed multiple enhancing lesions. Astereotactic biopsy of the cerebral lesions was done and the image is given below. Which ofthe following is the most appropriate drug for her treatment?
questions.explanation: SporozoitesCysts intissuesCystEggs shedin stoolTachyzoitesCysts intissuesOMARROW(bradyzoites)CarnivoryEndodyogenyMonocyteinvasionTachyzoitesIngestionTrophozoitesIntestinalcellsIngestionIntestinalcellsSporulated oocyst(2sporoblasts eachcontaining 4 sporozoites)SporogonyExternal environmentOMARROWOrgantransplantationBloodtransfusionDefinitive hosts:FelidsCyst ruptureShizontSchizogonyGamogonyMicro o/macro Q gametesOocyst547The given clinical scenario and the image showing lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophilssurrounding the toxoplasma bradyzoites which are encased in cysts are suggestive of cerebraltoxoplasmosis. Spiramycin is the drug of choice during pregnancy.Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection commonly found in HIV +ve patients andusually occurs when CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL.It appears as ring enhancing lesions on contrast enhanced CT. Calcification may also be seen inold lesions.Sabin-Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies againsttoxoplasma. IIF (indirect immunofluorescence), IHA (indirect heamagglutination), andCFT (complement fixation test) are also used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis. Dye test remainspositive throughout life, while CFT becomes negative soon after acute infection.ELISA is most commonly used and IgM and IgG antibodies are estimated separately.Standard treatment is sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4-6 weeks.The drug of choice for toxoplasmosis in pregnancy is spiramycin.

questions.question: A Kinyoun-positive oocyst (25 μm) isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea is shown in theimage. What is the likely organism implicated here?539
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian parasiticinfestation. Kinyoun-positive oocysts with the size of 25 μm in the image are formedby Cystoisospora.Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:The below image shows oocysts of Cyclospora cayetanensis in the modified acid-fast stain.PropertySporulated oocystAcid-fast detectionSporulation of the oocystDiagnostic formCryptosporidium4-6 μm, round, contains four sporozoitesUniformly acid fastOccurs inside the host cellSporulated cystCyclospora8-12 μm, round, contains2 sporocysts, each havingtwo sporozoitesVariable acid fastOccurs in soilUnsporulated cystCystoisospora23-36 um, oval, contain two sporocysts, each having four sporozoitesUniformly acid fastOccurs in soilUnsporulated oocyst548A10μmThe below image shows oocysts of Cryptosporidium parvum in the modified acid-fast stain.

questions.question: A patient who underwent a renal transplant 3 months ago came with complaints of diarrheafor the last 9 days. The stool sample subjected to Kinyoun staining revealed 4-6 μm structuresas shown below. Which of the following is true about the causative organism?

options.B: It is an obligate intracellular organism
options.C: Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool
options.D: Metronidazole is the drug of choice

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with Kinyoun stain positive oocysts of size 4-6 µm is suggestive ofcryptosporidiosis. The oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in the stool.Cryptosporidium is a coccidian parasite and implicated in causing traveler's diarrhea inimmunocompromised patients. The two cryptosporidium species responsible are C. hominis andC. parvum.The infective form is the oocyst excreted in the patient's feces, which can be acquired throughdrinking or during recreational water activities. The oocysts are immediately infectious (unlikeisospora oocysts, which require maturation), and may cause autoinfection or be implicated in549person-to-person transmission. Because of their small size (4-5micron), they is difficult to seeusing routine staining. Hence acid-fast/Kinyoun's stain is used.Once ingested, the 4 sporozoites are released from the cyst and attach to the small intestinalmucosa. It causes crampy abdominal pain and non-inflammatory watery diarrhea.Treatment is mainly supportive, though nitazoxanide has been FDA approved for use incryptosporidium infection.Comparative features of coccidian parasites:PropertySporulated oocystAcid-fast detectionSporulation of the oocystDiagnostic formCryptosporidium4-6 μm, round, contains four sporozoitesUniformly acid-fastOccurs inside the host cellSporulated cystCyclospora8-12 μm, round, contains2 sporocysts each having two sporozoitesVariable acid-fastOccurs in soilUnsporulated cystCystoisospora23-36 um, oval, contain two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites.Uniformly acid-fastOccurs in soilUnsporulated oocyst

questions.question: Match the following:
questions.explanation: The below image shows trophozoites of Trichomonas vaginalis with flagella.ParasiteBalamuthia mandrillarisBalantidium coliOrgan of locomotionPseudopodCiliaFlagellaTrichomonas vaginalisNo Particular orgaToxoplasma gondin550The below image shows the trophozoite of Balantidium coli with cilia.The below image shows the trophozoite of Balamuthia mandrillaris with pseudopodia.551b-110 μmThe below image shows tachyzoites of Toxoplasma gondi. They have no specialised structure forlocomotion.552
